Graphene foams, due to their excellent porous structure, are a light material that combines the properties of two-dimensional graphene sheets and the three-dimensional system they form when joined together. The large pore volume and subsequent high specific surface area of the material, its thermal stability, high electronic conductivity, and high ion transfer rate all contribute to graphene foams’ functionality in energy storage devices
28, 33, 34 . Hence, to further improve their properties, increase electrode capacity, and power or energy density, many researchers try to dope graphene materials with metal compounds or metal oxides, or to create composites with other active materials
35– 38 . These solutions involve increased production and disposal costs. The fact that these substances are not environmentally friendly leads researchers to try to introduce heteroatoms (mainly nitrogen) into the carbon structure using natural reagents
39, 40 , thus increasing the range of potential applications of 3D graphene materials.
